query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
1 Quando ambedue li figli di Latona, 2 coperti del Montone e de la Libra, 3 fanno de l’orizzonte insieme zona,
4 quant’ è dal punto che ’l cenìt inlibra 5 infin che l’uno e l’altro da quel cinto, 6 cambiando l’emisperio, si dilibra,
7 tanto, col volto di riso dipinto, 8 si tacque Bëatrice, riguardando 9 fiso nel punto che m’avëa vinto.
query.result:
**English:**
1 When both the children of Latona, 2 covered by Aries and Libra, 3 make a single belt of the horizon,
4 as much time as from the moment when the zenith is balanced 5 until one and the other from that belt, 6 changing hemisphere, are balanced,
7 so long, with her face painted with laughter, 8 Beatrice was silent, gazing fixedly 9 at the point that had conquered me.
**Cornish:**
1 Py lemmyn an dhew vab Latona, 2 kovrys gans an Montone ha’n Libra, 3 a wra dheudh a’n orizonti zonan unn,
4 kemmys a-ugh a’n poynt pan wosa’n zenith yn libra, 5 bys dheudh an unn ha’n erel a’n gweli, 6 ow chanjya’n an emisferi, yw libra,
7 kemmys, gans y fas peyntis gans lowenj, 8 Beatrice a wra dheudh tewes, ow regardya 9 fiso yn an poynt a wra dheudh vy gwaynya.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
10 Poi cominciò: «Io dico, e non dimando, 11 quel che tu vuoli udir, perch’ io l’ho visto 12 là ’ve s’appunta ogne ubi e ogne quando.
query.result:
**English:**
10 Then she began: “I say, and do not ask, 11 what you want to hear, because I saw it 12 there where every where and every when is fixed.”
**Cornish:**
10 Wosa hi: “Vy a lever, ha nyns eus owth gorra, 11 an peth a vynsi dheudh klev, rag vy a’n gwelas 12 eno pan yw ogne ubi ha ogne quando owth appunta.”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
13 Non per aver a sé di bene acquisto, 14 ch’esser non può, ma perché suo splendore 15 potesse, risplendendo, dir “Subsisto”,
16 in sua etternità di tempo fore, 17 fuor d’ogne altro comprender, come i piacque, 18 s’aperse in nuovi amor l’etterno amore.
query.result:
**English:**
13 Not in order to have for itself an acquisition of good, 14 which cannot be, but so that its splendor 15 might, by shining, say “I exist”,
16 in its eternity of time before, 17 outside of every other comprehension, as it pleased it, 18 the eternal love opened itself in new loves.
**Cornish:**
13 Nyns yw rag dheudh gwaynya dheudh y honen gwell, 14 rag nyns yw possybyl, mes rag y splender 15 a alla, ow splenderi, leverel “Vy a-ugh”,
16 yn y eternita a-ugh termyn a-rag, 17 a-ves a ogne komprehendya erel, dell owth kar, 18 yn karanteth nowyth an garanteth etern a wra dheudh agori.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
19 Né prima quasi torpente si giacque; 20 ché né prima né poscia procedette 21 lo discorrer di Dio sovra quest’ acque.

Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
22 Forma e materia, congiunte e purette, 23 usciro ad esser che non avia fallo, 24 come d’arco tricordo tre saette.
query.result:
**English:**
22 Form and matter, joined yet pure, 23 came forth to be that which had no fault, 24 like three arrows from a three-stringed bow.
**Cornish:**
22 Furv ha mater, kevrednys mes par, 23 a dheuth ha bos na vea kamm gwella, 24 avel tri saeth a bow tri-korden.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
25 E come in vetro, in ambra o in cristallo 26 raggio resplende sì, che dal venire 27 a l’esser tutto non è intervallo,
28 così ’l triforme effetto del suo sire 29 ne l’esser suo raggiò insieme tutto 30 sanza distinzïone in essordire.
query.result:
**English:**
25 And as in glass, in amber, or in crystal 26 a ray shines so that between its coming 27 and its being there is no interval,
28 so the threefold effect of its maker 29 in its being shone forth all at once 30 without distinction in its beginning.
**Cornish:**
25 Ha glaw, en amber po en kristal 26 a wragh splann mar, hemma dhe dhyski 27 dhe bos, nyns eus interval,
28 hemma an effeyth tri-furv a'y syra 29 en y bos a wragh splann oll orth 30 heb distinsi orth y dhalleth.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
46 Or sai tu dove e quando questi amori 47 furon creati e come: sì che spenti 48 nel tuo disïo già son tre ardori.
query.result:
**English:**
46 Now you know where, when, and how these loves 47 were created: so that three fires are now quenched 48 in your desire.
**Cornish:**
46 Wosa tys owna le may ha pan hemma an karow 47 a veu kreysi ha gans penau: marow henna 48 yn dha desyr tri ardur a veu kweyth.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
49 Né giugneriesi, numerando, al venti 50 sì tosto, come de li angeli parte 51 turbò il suggetto d’i vostri alimenti.
query.result:
**English:**
49 Nor would you reach twenty, counting, 50 as quickly as the part of the angels 51 disturbed the subject of your nourishment.
**Cornish:**
49 Na'th fyttye bythyn, ow konta, dhe'n ugans 50 mar dhammalvel avel rann a'n eleth 51 a drubas an sojet a'gan boesow.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
52 L’altra rimase, e cominciò quest’ arte 53 che tu discerni, con tanto diletto, 54 che mai da circüir non si diparte.
query.result:
**English:**
52 The other remained, and began this art 53 that you discern, with so much delight, 54 that it never departs from its circling.
**Cornish:**
52 An aral a veu remenys, ha a dhallethas an art ma 53 tys a wra'n gweles, gans hemma an les, 54 hemma ny wra veur dasserhi a'y syrkel.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
55 Principio del cader fu il maladetto 56 superbir di colui che tu vedesti 57 da tutti i pesi del mondo costretto.
query.result:
**English:**
55 The beginning of the fall was the cursed 56 pride of him whom you saw 57 weighed down by all the burdens of the world.
**Cornish:**
55 Penn an kodha veu an malledys 56 surbir a henna neb tys a welas 57 gans oll an posow a'n bys a veu kostek.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
58 Quelli che vedi qui furon modesti 59 a riconoscer sé da la bontate 60 che li avea fatti a tanto intender presti:
61 per che le viste lor furo essaltate 62 con grazia illuminante e con lor merto, 63 si c’hanno ferma e piena volontate;
64 e non voglio che dubbi, ma sia certo, 65 che ricever la grazia è meritorio 66 secondo che l’affetto l’è aperto.
query.result:
**English:**
58 Those whom you see here were modest 59 in acknowledging themselves to be from the goodness 60 that had made them so quick to understand:
61 for which their sight was exalted 62 with illuminating grace and with their merit, 63 so that they have a firm and full will;
64 and I do not want you to doubt, but be certain, 65 that receiving grace is meritorious 66 according to how open the affection is to it.
**Cornish:**
58 Henna neb tys a wel dres ma veu modys 59 dhe gorra aga honen gans an da 60 neb a veu aga gwreys mar dhammalvel dhe welas:
61 rag hemma aga golwg veu essoltys 62 gans gras owthholyans ha gans aga meryt, 63 marow henna aga bos ferm ha leun voladow;
64 ha nyns eus karas dhe dhoubtya, mes bos dhe vos sur, 65 bos dhe dhe resevya gras yw merytoryel 66 herwydh hemma an effek a vos dhegor dhe.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
67 Omai dintorno a questo consistorio 68 puoi contemplare assai, se le parole 69 mie son ricolte, sanz’ altro aiutorio.
query.result:
**English:**
67 Now around this consistory 68 you can contemplate much, if my words 69 are understood, without any other help.
**Cornish:**
67 Wosa owna a-dro dhe'n konsistori ma 68 tys a yll kontemplya liesow, ma'm gerow 69 yw dhe resevya, heb heler aral.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
70 Ma perché ’n terra per le vostre scole 71 si legge che l’angelica natura 72 è tal, che ’ntende e si ricorda e vole,
73 ancor dirò, perché tu veggi pura 74 la verità che là giù si confonde, 75 equivocando in sì fatta lettura.
query.result:
**English:**
70 But why on earth do your schools teach 71 that angelic nature 72 is such that it understands, remembers, and wills,
73 I will also say, so that you may see clearly 74 the truth that is confused down there, 75 through misinterpretation of such reading.
**Cornish:**
70 Mes ragath pow orth y’gan skolyow 71 a leverir anedha natur ael 72 yw keth, ow komprehendya, kovya ha desira,
73 vyth wra vyth leverel, rag omwelowgh 74 an wiryonedh owth yw kemyskys dhegys, 75 dre wosa-komprehendya an keth leverans.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
76 Queste sustanze, poi che fur gioconde 77 de la faccia di Dio, non volser viso 78 da essa, da cui nulla si nasconde:
79 però non hanno vedere interciso 80 da novo obietto, e però non bisogna 81 rememorar per concetto diviso;
82 sì che là giù, non dormendo, si sogna, 83 credendo e non credendo dicer vero; 84 ma ne l’uno è più colpa e più vergogna.
query.result:
**English:**
76 These substances, after they were joyful 77 in the presence of God, did not turn their face 78 from him, from whom nothing is hidden:
79 therefore they have their vision uninterrupted 80 by any new object, and therefore they do not need 81 to remember through a separate concept;
82 so that down there, without sleeping, they dream, 83 believing and not believing that they are telling the truth; 84 but in the one case there is more fault and more shame.
**Cornish:**
76 An substansow ma, wosa oedh lowen 77 orth an fas a Dhew, ny wodhsa an golwg 78 dhyworthsa, orth neb ny wodh kudhis.
79 Rag henna, y’gans na wodh an golwg 80 torrys gans nowyth ober, ha rag henna 81 ny wodh i re-kovya dre gonsept rannys.
82 Marow henna, dhegys, heb kows, ymonsons, 83 ow kredis ha na gredis ow leveris an wiryonedh; 84 mes y’gan unn yw moy culpa ha moy onour.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
85 Voi non andate giù per un sentiero 86 filosofando: tanto vi trasporta 87 l’amor de l’apparenza e ’l suo pensiero!
88 E ancor questo qua sù si comporta 89 con men disdegno che quando è posposta 90 la divina Scrittura o quando è torta.
query.result:
**English:**
85 You do not go down by a single path 86 philosophizing: so much does 87 the love of appearances and the thought of it transport you!
88 And even this up here is tolerated 89 with less disdain than when 90 divine Scripture is neglected or distorted.
**Cornish:**
85 Why ny wodhvos ow tos orth unn fordh 86 ow filosofieth: kemmys yw’gan karga 87 an karanteth an seblans ha’y bowes!
88 Ha henna ma, yma dhegys, yw godhvos 89 gans moy desdeyn ages pan vo postet 90 an Skriftyur Dhiwin po pan vo tortet.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
91 Non vi si pensa quanto sangue costa 92 seminarla nel mondo e quanto piace 93 chi umilmente con essa s’accosta.
query.result:
**English:**
91 You do not think how much blood it cost 92 to sow it in the world, and how much it pleases 93 those who humbly approach it.
**Cornish:**
91 Why ny wodhvos ow pos pyth kemmys gwydh 92 ow’y sevel y’n bys ma ha pyth moy lowen 93 dhe’n neb ow tos yn omble gans an Skryftur.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
94 Per apparer ciascun s’ingegna e face 95 sue invenzioni; e quelle son trascorse 96 da’ predicanti e ’l Vangelio si tace.
query.result:
**English:**
94 To appear learned, each one exerts himself and makes 95 his own inventions; and these are spread abroad 96 by the preachers, and the Gospel is silent.
**Cornish:**
94 Rag om sevel dyskys, pub onan a wra 95 ow kul ow invenshens; ha’y re beu tremensys 96 gans an bregethoryon, ha’n Gospyl yw tewlys.

**English:**
97 One says that the moon turned away 98 at the passion of Christ and interposed itself, 99 so that the light of the sun would not reach the earth;
100 and he is wrong, because the light hid 101 of its own accord: therefore to the Spanish and to the Indians 102 as to the Jews such an eclipse appeared.
**Cornish:**
97 Onan a lever may an loer a droas 98 y’n passion Krist ha’ynterposyas, 99 rag na wodhsa golow an howl a sevel orth.
100 Ha’n fol, rag an golow a gudhas 101 dhyworthsa honan: rag henna dhe’n Spaynyoryon ha dhe’n Indyoryon 102 keth ha dhe’n Yedhovyon keth ekl ips a welas.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
103 Non ha Fiorenza tanti Lapi e Bindi 104 quante sì fatte favole per anno 105 in pergamo si gridan quinci e quindi:
106 sì che le pecorelle, che non sanno, 107 tornan del pasco pasciute di vento, 108 e non le scusa non veder lo danno.
query.result:
**English:**
103 Florence has not so many Lapis and Bindis 104 as there are such fables in a year 105 shouted from the pulpit here and there:
106 so that the little sheep, who do not know, 107 return from the pasture fed on wind, 108 and their not seeing the harm does not excuse them.
**Cornish:**
103 Nyns eus dhe’n cita a Vrans may Lapi ha Bindi 104 ages keth istori avel orth y’n bledhen 105 y’n pergamo a leverir yma ha allá:
106 Marow henna, an avalow, neb ny wodh, 107 a dheuth orth an paska ow pos gwyns, 108 ha ny wodh i escusa na wodhvos gweles an drok.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
115 Ora si va con motti e con iscede 116 a predicare, e pur che ben si rida, 117 gonfia il cappuccio e più non si richiede.
query.result:
**English:**
115 Now one goes with jests and witticisms 116 to preach, and provided that people laugh heartily, 117 the hood swells and nothing more is required.
**Cornish:**
115 Mes lemmyn onan a tos gans gerensow ha gwythow 116 dhe bregetha, ha pub tra veur ben lowen, 117 an kapuchin a wodh gorrys ha nyns eus moy rekisys.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
118 Ma tale uccel nel becchetto s’annida, 119 che se ’l vulgo il vedesse, vederebbe 120 la perdonanza di ch’el si confida:
121 per cui tanta stoltezza in terra crebbe, 122 che, sanza prova d’alcun testimonio, 123 ad ogne promession si correrebbe.
query.result:
**English:**
118 But such a bird nests in the little beak, 119 that if the common people saw it, they would see 120 the pardon in which they trust:
121 because of which so much folly has grown on earth, 122 that, without proof of any testimony, 123 people would run to any promise.
**Cornish:**
118 Mes keth ethen a wodh y’n bygan beak, 119 pub tra veur an bobel a’y gwelas, a welas 120 an pardon orth neb yma yma y fydh.
121 Rag henna kemmys folneth yw kresys y’n bys, 122 heb proevidh a neb testymoni, 123 dhe pub promisyon onan a redhas.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
124 Di questo ingrassa il porco sant’ Antonio, 125 e altri assai che sono ancor più porci, 126 pagando di moneta sanza conio.
query.result:
**English:**
124 Saint Anthony fattens himself on this, 125 and many others who are even greater pigs, 126 paying with counterfeit money.
**Cornish:**
124 An Sant Anton a wra dhe'nwedhen ma, 125 ha neb es elsi a wra moy porci, 126 ow paya moneta heb cownya.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
127 Ma perché siam digressi assai, ritorci 128 li occhi oramai verso la dritta strada, 129 sì che la via col tempo si raccorci.
query.result:
**English:**
127 But since we have digressed too much, turn 128 your eyes now toward the straight road, 129 so that the journey may be shortened with time.
**Cornish:**
127 Mes drehevys owth omdhiskwedhys moy, try 128 dha'ganenvyth wosa dhe fordh onan, 129 rag an fordh gans an amser a wra berr.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
136 La prima luce, che tutta la raia, 137 per tanti modi in essa si recepe, 138 quanti son li splendori a chi s’appaia.
query.result:
**English:**
136 The first light, which illumines everything, 137 is received in it in as many ways 138 as there are splendors to which it appears.
**Cornish:**
136 An kynsa golow, a wra owth goleugh oll, 137 a wra resevyes ynni yn moy yn moy a fordhow, 138 kepar ha'n niver a splannderow dhe'n wra owth omdhiskwedhes.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
139 Onde, però che a l’atto che concepe 140 segue l’affetto, d’amar la dolcezza 141 diversamente in essa ferve e tepe.
query.result:
**English:**
139 Therefore, since the act of conceiving 140 is followed by the affection of loving the sweetness, 141 it waxes and wanes differently in it.
**Cornish:**
139 Rag drehevys, rag dhe'n ober a wra omdhiskwedhes, 140 a wra sewya an affectyon a gara an melyster, 141 yn fordhow dyffrans ynni a wra owth omdhiskwedhes ha owth omdhiskwedha.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
142 Vedi l’eccelso omai e la larghezza 143 de l’etterno valor, poscia che tanti 144 speculi fatti s’ha in che si spezza,
145 uno manendo in sé come davanti».
query.result:
**English:**
142 Now you see the height and the breadth 143 of the eternal value, since it has made so many 144 mirrors in which it is broken up,
145 while remaining one in itself as before."
**Cornish:**
142 Weles an ughella ha an levedh 143 a'n gwerth ewig, drehevys ev a wra gwres 144 moy a spyklysow gwres yn aga wra owth omdhiskwedhes,
145 ow pobos ynni ynni kepar ha kyns.
